channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Blast Kills 3 in South Beirut Suburbs
item.description: A powerful car bomb ripped through a southern Beirut neighborhood that is a stronghold of the militant group Hezbollah on Thursday, killing at least three people and trapping others in burning buildings, the media said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Death Toll in Egypt Clashes Climbs to 525
item.description: Muslim Brotherhood supporters of the deposed president, Mohamed Morsi, called for demonstrations on Thursday, a day after security forces stormed two protest camps in a bloody assault that set off a violent backlash across Egypt.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: A man grieved on Wednesday over bodies at a makeshift morgue.

item.title: Relatives of Slain Briton Demanded Up to $8 Million in Compensation, Lawyer Says
item.description: The lawyer, who was not directly involved in negotiations between the family of the slain man, Neil Heywood, and the Chinese woman who killed him, said the amount demanded was in flux.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: In Rebuke to Egypt, Obama Cancels Joint Military Exercises
item.description: Speaking from Martha’s Vineyard on Thursday, Obama warned of future steps but made no mention of cutting off military and economic aid to Egypt.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: The events in Cairo set off a violent backlash across Egypt.

item.title: Letter From Europe: ‘Fracking’ Debate Divides Britain
item.description: A campaign by Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain to emulate the United States' success in hydraulic fracturing has touched the emotional ties that bind an island nation to its land.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: August 15
item.description: Schoolchildren, dressed in tricolors, participating in Independence Day celebrations in Delhi.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Schoolchildren taking part in Independence Day celebrations in front of the Red Fort monument in Delhi.

item.title: News Analysis: Arab Spring Countries Find Peace Is Harder Than Revolution
item.description: The violence in Egypt has underscored how the Arab Spring revolutions have devolved into bitter political power struggles among competing groups.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: People protested Bahrain’s government on Wednesday behind barbed wire placed by the police.

item.title: India Ink: 18 Indian Navy Men Feared Dead After Submarine Explosion
item.description: Divers struggling to save 18 Indian sailors trapped after their submarine caught fire and exploded in Mumbai.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: Navy chief Admiral D.K. Joshi, left, talking to Defense Minister A.K. Antony, second from left, as divers standing on the INS Sindhurakshak submarine prepare to dive into the waters during a rescue operation in Mumbai, Maharashtra, on Wednesday.

item.title: India Ink: Freedom for Midnight’s Daughters
item.description: India has miles to go before its women find a full measure of freedom.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By AMANA FONTANELLA-KHAN

item.title: Car Bombs Hit Iraqi Capital Killing 33 People
item.description: More than 3,000 people have been killed in violence during the past few months, raising fears Iraq could see a new round of widespread sectarian bloodshed.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Japan’s Premier Stays Away From War Shrine, but Sends Offering
item.description: Shinzo Abe’s compromise failed to mollify China, which summoned Japan’s envoy to protest visits to the Yasukuni shrine by ministers in Mr. Abe’s cabinet.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: South Korea Proposes Talks to Reunite War-Divided Families
item.description: President Park Geun-hye’s conciliatory overtures Thursday came amid signs that South and North Korea are moving toward a thaw after months of tensions.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: The Lede: Updates on Security Crackdown in Egypt
item.description: The Lede is following events in Egypt on Wednesday, where the security forces used deadly force to disperse sit-ins by supporters of the deposed president, Mohamed Morsi.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY and LIAM STACK
item.media:credit: Aly Hazzaa/El Shorouk Newspaper, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An Egyptian police jeep fell from the October 6 Bridge during clashes with Islamist protesters in Cairo on Wednesday.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan Says Indian Military Killed a Civilian in Kashmir
item.description: Pakistani military officials said the Indian military had killed a civilian, the latest in a round of accusations of cross-border violations in the disputed region of Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Hezbollah Claims Bombing That Wounded 4 Israeli Soldiers
item.description: Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of Hezbollah, said members of his party were behind a bombing last week that wounded four Israeli soldiers.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Mali: Leader of a Coup Gets a Promotion
item.description: Mali’s departing interim president promoted to the rank of general an army captain who led a coup last year that plunged the nation into crisis.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Lithuania: Court Orders Russian Sent to United States
item.description: The court on Wednesday ordered the extradition to the United States of Dmitry Ustinov, a Russian suspected of illegal arms dealing.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Israel Releases Palestinian Prisoners
item.description: As part of an American-brokered deal, Israel released 26 Palestinian prisoners, spawning protests in Tel Aviv and celebrations in Ramallah.

item.title: The Lede: Scores Killed in Crackdown on Morsi Supporters
item.description: The scale and brutality of the attack on supporters of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi, was the clearest sign yet that the old Egyptian police state was re-emerging in full force.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Leeds Journal: Giving Troubled Youth a Chance to Leap and Soar
item.description: A highly disciplined dance boot camp has become one of the most successful programs for troubled youths in Britain.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:description: Youth unemployment is soaring in the north of England.

item.title: U.S. Seeks Arrest of Mexican Kingpin Who Was Freed in American’s Murder
item.description: Rafael Caro Quintero was the mastermind of the 1985 killing of Agent Enrique Camarena and two other Americans and served 28 years of a 40-year sentence.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: Fierce and Swift Raids on Islamists Bring Sirens, Gunfire, Then Screams
item.description: The military-backed government in Egypt had hinted at a milder clearing operation that would last days. But when it came, protesters appeared stunned by its fury.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and MAYY EL SHEIKH

item.title: Hundreds Die as Egyptian Forces Attack Islamist Protesters
item.description: The scale and brutality of the attack on supporters of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi, was the clearest sign yet that the old Egyptian police state was re-emerging in full force.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:credit: Narciso Contreras for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wounded protesters laid on the floor of a field hospital in Cairo following clashes.

item.title: Old Economies Rise as Growing Markets Begin to Falter
item.description: Economies in Japan and the United States are growing and Europe appears to be easing away from a recession just as growth is slowing in Brazil, Russia, India and China.
item.dc:creator: By NATHANIEL POPPER

item.title: U.S. Condemns Crackdown but Announces No Policy Shift
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry did not disclose any specific American response to the assault on Morsi supporters.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:credit: Sabry Khaled/El Shorouk Newspaper, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A member of the Egyptian security forces lay on the ground and another on his vehicle after it was pushed off a bridge in Cairo.
